summary.seg: Cambridge, University Library, MS Kk.6.33 is a fifteenth-century composite manuscript that contains a wealth of medical texts across its codicologically distinct parts. Part 1 is comprised of two leaves which contain medical recipes in French and English, copied by a fifteenth-century hand in different stints and inks; a different fifteenth-century hand has added to these a note in Latin on the medical virtues of the crocus plant. The ink foliation in the middle of the top of the leaves ('xxi' and 'liii') indicate that they have come from a larger (now lost) collection, which may have belonged to a 'Robert Pedwardine', whose name is written on the top of ff. ii recto–ii verso. Part 2 is a collection of astronomical tables and texts copied out very neatly by a single scribe in black, red and blue ink in a single cursive script with some features of textualis. Part 3, the most extensive, contains medical recipes and charms (mainly in English but occasionally in Latin) interspersed with other medical texts, such as: a treatise on wounds and the plague; instructions on the best times to let blood; an extract from a herbal; and information on the perilous days of the year. Multiple hands (described in more detail below) contribute to this part of the manuscript at different times, demonstrating that large collections of recipes like this could move between many different readers and owners, who would each add to, adapt, and correct the healing information they inherited. Later readers could also impose order upon that information: from f. 2:29r, numbers appear alongside the recipes in Part 3 of the codex, suggesting that a later reader wished to compile a list of contents, in order to make individual recipes easier to locate.

This accumulation of knowledge over time by multiple readers and scribes is immediately apparent in the first quire of Part 3 (ff. 2:1r-2:10v). Between ff. 2:3r-2:7v, a fifteenth-century hand has copied a collection of medical recipes; on f. 2:7v, the same hand may have added a recipe at a later point in time in a different ink. On ff. 2:1r–2:2v, 2:6v–2:7r, 2:8r–2:10v, as many as six other hands have later added recipes before, after, and amongst those medical recipes. This opening quire seems once to have existed separately from the rest of Part 3 as a booklet, which originally contained blank leaves before and after the main body of recipes; those blank leaves were then filled by the later hands. The thinness and greater discoloration of the parchment in this quire (compared to the parchment comprising the later quires of Part 3) support this. One of the hands that adds recipes into this opening quire (ff. 2:2v, 2:6v–2:7r, 2:8r, 2:8v–2:10v) also adds them into the quires that come after, indicating that, when this scribe was reading the manuscript, the quires comprising Part 3 were all part of one codex.

In the remaining quires comprising Part 3, the majority of the texts are copied by another fifteenth-century hand in a neat variety of Anglicana Formata. The medical recipes and treatises (on wounds, bloodletting and the plague) copied by this hand seem well-suited to an educated medical practitioner: the recipes normally contain precise quantities; electuaries are referred to through their technical pharmaceutical names such as 'diagalanga' and 'diapenydion' (f. 2:24v) and it is expected that the reader will already have these to hand or know how to prepare them without further instruction. Furthermore, the recipes normally refer to the patient in the third person (indicating that the intended reader is a practitioner who will administer the recipe to that patient's body) and many of the recipe collections display a recurrent interest in surgical matters such as wounds and broken bones. There is, however, a more homely, culinary reference on f. 2:66r where the reader is instructed to 'oyle ϸi handis as ϸou woldist do gyngerbrede'. This instruction may have been copied wholesale from an exemplar but it nevertheless demonstrates how closely entangled culinary processes, spaces and ingredients were with medical preparations.

Whilst copying these medical texts, this scribe occasionally leaves gaps between recipes; he may have intended to return to these and add additional recipes or supply something that was missing in his exemplar from a different source. Sometimes, the text supplied in these gaps does look like it could have been added by this scribe at a later date in a slightly modified script (e.g. f. 2:36v-2:37r). Elsewhere, however, one of the hands who added recipes to the first quire of Part 3 has inserted material into these gaps. For instance, on f. 2:100r, in a recipe for an affliction of the bones, the main scribe has broken off copying mid-recipe after the phrase 'do hem on shepis'. The later scribe has completed this instruction by adding in 'lethir for fowling of your lynyn clothis'. In the rest of the gap left by the main scribe on the reverse side of the leaf, this later scribe has then proceeded to add a different recipe for 'water of coperose'. He gives the original text a neater and clearer end before squeezing in additional information to make the most efficient use of the space within the codex.

This scribe adds recipes into many other places too. Sometimes, his efforts to squeeze in additional information confuse the text: for instance, on f. 2:71v, he adds a recipe at the bottom of the leaf for a woman who has not had a rite of purification after childbirth; this insertion disrupts the prose of the main scribe's unrelated recipe for 'watir of borage' which is copied across the folios. In contrast, on f. 2:77r, this later scribe has added a remedy for gout, sciatica, podagra and other ailments after a remedy by the main scribe for dropsy, sciatica and podagra. Here, the later reader has made use of the gap left by the first scribe to group information together in a way that makes it more usable, locatable and comparable. Elsewhere, this hand also corrects the text of the main scribe after it has been damaged or part of it has been lost. For instance, a missing leaf means that the remedy at the top of f. 2:48r is acephalous. However, the scribe has added in a title and supplied the imperative 'take' before the first named ingredient, in order to give the recipe a clear beginning; the recipe is here turned into something usable and it now reads as complete.

This scribe's corrections and additions show how recipe collections could become collaborative, patchwork texts over time, as different hands reshaped and extended them. The texts in MS Kk.6.33 are patchwork compilations of voices in other respects too. I have noted elsewhere that some of the recipes within the manuscript reproduce - without acknowledgement - personal anecdotes wholesale from other sources. For instance, on f. 2:109v, there is an anecdote after a recipe for valence of wormode (wormwood) beginning 'This y haue muche yvsyd and louyd for withe it I helid a sherve at Bristowe the whiche of ϸe prikyng of a smal dager poynt in the lacert of the lift arme for peyne bolnyng brennyng and crampe was nye ded thorugh an vnhappi cure of a barboure...'. Similar versions of the recipe and the anecdote appear in other fifteenth- and sixteenth-century manuscripts (such as Cambridge, Magdalene College, MS Pepys 878, p. 160 and Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Ashmole 1389, pp. 221–22). Both seem to have been adapted from the writings of the fourteenth-century English surgeon, John Arderne. The scribe of MS Kk.6.33 may have copied this anecdote wholesale from another Middle English recipe collection without any awareness of Ardene's text. But, wherever he copied it from, it is testament to how comfortable scribes and compilers were reproducing within their own manuscripts the personal voices and testimonies of others.

MS Kk.6.33 also contains several charms, which invite readers to imagine the codex supporting other kinds of vocal performance too: three charms occur in the first quire of Part 3. The charms are for treating burns and scalds (f. 2:4r), for breaking a swelling (f. 2:4v), and for healing wounds (f. 2:5r). The charm for the swelling contains many performative utterances, which suggest an oral performance: 'I aske leue of oure lady...I blisse ϸis breste...'. However, the end of the charm contains the instruction 'Set that worde ϸer ϸou wilt haue hit ybroke'. This may invite the reader to apply the charm to the body in a written form. The charm for burns also displays an interesting hybridity: as T.M. Smallwood notes (2008, p. 89), it is written in 'unrhymed free verse'. Although the charm is written out in lines of prose, puncti indicate where verse lineation could be imposed; a refrain also reverberates across the charm, increasing its memorability and its capacity to charm readers in the multiple different senses of that word.

Other texts in the manuscript similarly appeal to readers' capacity for wonder: at the end of a series of recipes for medicinal preparations, it is written 'who so euer can worche wiþ ϸes wateris and oylis and askis schuld be namyd more a prophet ϸan a leche' (f. 2:75v). In these lines, a magnificent confidence is instilled in the reader: the preparations are so failproof that the 'leche' or physician using them will be able to foretell the patient's recovery with the confidence of a prophet. Regardless of whether this startling guarantee was taken seriously or seen as rhetorical bombast, it may have been a refreshing change from the difficult processes of trial-and-error that inevitably confronted medieval medical practitioners and users of large compendiums of recipes.

Dr Hannah Bower
Faculty of English
University of Cambridge

listBibl.bibl: Hannah Bower, 'The Brickmaker, the Tavernkeeper, and the Knight: The Role of Obscurity and Imagination in Medieval Medical Recipes', in Recipes and Book Culture in England, 1350–1600, ed. by Carrie Griffin and Hannah Ryley (Liverpool: Liverpool University Press, 2024), pp. 95-117
T.M. Smallwood, 'Conformity and Originality in Middle English Charms', in Charms, Charmers and Charming, ed. by Jonathan Roper (Basingstoke: Palgrave Macmillan, 2008), pp. 87–99

extent.seg: v + 2 | 15 | 92 + iv leaves. Blank paper leaves have been added at various places in the manuscript, specifically after the first two medieval leaves, and at points where medieval leaves are no longer present. For this statement of extent, these internal, modern leaves have not been counted. In one instance, a paper leaf has been added in order to provide a mount for a fragmentary leaf that would otherwise be detached from the manuscript (f. 1:7a). Since there is still a remnant of a medieval leaf that bears writing, this has been counted in this statement. This fragment was previously unfoliated but has now been assigned the number '7a'.

foliation.note: Numbering in brown ink at the centre of the upper margins on both the rectos and versos.
Numbering in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos.
Numbering in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos.

This catalogue record follows the 16th- and 20th-century foliation, adding folio numbers between square brackets for the modern paper leaves that have been inserted between the manuscript's original paper and parchment leaves. Due to the recurrence of numbers in the folio sequences of parts 2 and 3, these sequences have been attributed unique numbers ('1' and '2') and folio references to leaves within these parts are now preceded by these numbers. The modern foliation that is used in this record is as follows: [a]-[e], i-ii, [iia]-[iib] | 1:1-1:7, 1:7a, 1:8, [1:8a], 1:9-1:14 | 2:1-2:12, [2:12a]-[2:12b], 2:23-2:26, [2:26a]-[2:26b], 2:29-2:31, 2:33-2:53, [2:53a]-[2:53h], 2:62-2:113, [f]-[i].

collation.formula: 12 | 210-2 (10th missing and most of 8th missing) 36 | 410 5two 68-4 (1st-2nd and 7th-8th missing) 7-118 128+1 (1 leaf inserted after 8th) 1310 148 158+1 (1 leaf inserted after 8th).
collation.note: This collation differs significantly from that of M.R. James, which also contains some errors. Since this manuscript counts ff. i-ii as the first quire, the quire numbering in pencil in the lower right-hand corner of the recto side of the first leaf of each quire in the manuscript is out of step by 1 with the formula given in this description. A gap in the 16th-century foliation points to the loss of a complete quire between Quires 9 (ff. 2:46-2:53) and 10 (ff. 2:62-2:69); to indicate this, eight blank paper leaves were added when the manuscript was rebound.

binding.p: Half leather binding with marbled paper sides and white paper pastedowns on the inside covers, bound Stoakley ('Bound by Stoakley , late Hawes') of Cambridge, dated 1894 on the inside cover.

provenance.p: John Moore (1646-1714), bishop of Ely Moore, John, 1646-1714 : no. 152 in Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (c. 1697).

history.acquisition: Presented to the University Library in 1715 by George I George I, King of Great Britain, 1660-1727 : donation bookplate engraved by John Pine Pine, John, 1690-1756 in 1736 on f. 2:113v.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on M. Connolly, Manuscripts in the University Library, Cambridge (Dd-Oo), Index of Middle English Prose, 19 (Cambridge: Brewer, 2009), and an unpublished description of the manuscript composed between 1926 and 1930 by M.R. JamesJames, M.R. (Montague Rhodes), 1862-1936, now held in the University Archives (UA ULIB 7/3/74).

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Kk.6.33, ff. i-ii

msContents.textLang: Middle English, Middle French and Latin

msItem.title: Collection of five medical recipes
msItem.note: Contains Middle English a recipe for wounds, cankers, worms, sinews, sores; abcesses; heartburn; to clean the heart, with a few notes in Latin; and aches and pain.

msItem.title: Medical recipes for all pains
msItem.rubric: i verso Cest medicyn est espoue bone pour toutz les pissions et toutz dolours del corps del home [etc.]
msItem.incipit: i verso Pernez comyn, peyuer, bays de lorer, pions, pelestre
msItem.explicit: i verso Cest medicyn un sarazine la prist a vn chiualer cristien pour qi amour il guerpi soun loy et deuient cristien et vnct on le chiualer et per cest medicyn un euesqe de herford qui longement languist il fuist garry la on nul autre luy p[...] valer
msItem.note: Ends with a note on a (?) payment apud Boston.

msItem.title: Recipe for a lead oxide plaster
msItem.rubric: ii recto For to make blake entrete
msItem.incipit: ii recto Tak j poudre liturge aureum and breke it into riȝt smal poudre
msItem.explicit: ii recto and þe plaistres of it most be drawen on lethir for cloþ is not strong ynoȝe þerto

msItem.title: Recipe for Diarrhoea
msItem.incipit: ii recto Pernez milfoill et plantayn

msItem.title: Recipe for erysipelas (inflammation)
msItem.rubric: ii verso For þe wilde fire and all maner hetes
msItem.incipit: ii verso Stille þe water of letuse and þan when þou haste þis watur wesche þe place þat is sore of þe fire þerwiþ
msItem.explicit: ii verso and he didde on þe same maner as it is seyd bifore and it esie him gretely

msItem.title: Note on the medicinal virtues of the crocus
msItem.note: Added in a different 15th-century hand.

p.secFol: ii recto ffor to make blake entrete

supportDesc.condition: Stains on f. ii recto obscure some of the recipes.

layout.seg: No ruling. Single columns. 24-37 lines to the page.

handNote.p: Written by different hands writing in cursive scripts, predominantly Anglicana but also including Secretary features.

decoNote.p: Two small capitals highlighted in red ink on f. ii recto.

history.provenance: i recto-ii verso: 'Robert Pedward.': perhaps Robert Pedwardine Pedwardine, Robert : his name inscribed in the upper right-hand corner of f. ii recto and upper left-hand corner of f. ii verso in a 15th-century script.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Kk.6.33, ff. 1:1r-1:14v

msItem.title: Table with dominical letters for the liturgical year
msItem.note: Some English is used in the column headings: Dominical letteris, Estreday, Whitsonday, From Christmas to Quadragesima, From Whitsonday to midsomer, and From pentecost to aduent.

msItem.title: Astronomical Kalendar
msItem.note: The Kalendar consists of a liturgical calendar with feasts from the Sanctorale and Temporale flankes by columns with astronomical information; each month is opposed by a page with tables for three consecutive lunar cycles in a year, which are identified as 1463, 1482, and 1501; the leaves containing August and October are torn out, with a small fragment of August remaining.
Some English is used in the column headings, noumbre of dayes, dawnyng, sun risyng, [sign of the Zodiac] greis, houris of planet, sonsettyng, derknyght.
Highlighted in red ink are David and Chad (March), Erkenwald (April), Edith (September), Winifred and Erkenwald (November).

msItem.title: Table of the moon's passage through the signs of the Zodiac
Table of lunar month's
msItem.note: Numerical table (no text).

msItem.title: Table giving the signs of the planets ruling over the daytime hours
msItem.note: The days of the week are given in Middle English: Sunday, monday, tuesday, wednysday, þursday, friday, and saturday.

msItem.title: Table of the Planetary Houses
msItem.incipit: 1:13v13v Capricornus - Aquarius: domus saturni - libra

msItem.title: Astrological verse
msItem.incipit: 1:13v Jupiter et venus bona sunt . Saturnus marsque malignus . Mercurius medius sol et luna mediocres.
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Astrological verse
msItem.incipit: 1:14r Aries hathe þe hede taurus þe neke and þe þrote gemin þe schuldris armes and handis cancer þe brest and stomak leo þe bake virgo þe wombe libra þe naule scorpio haþe þe preuy membres sagittarius þe sharis capricornus the kneis aquarius the shankis pisses þe fett also blede not in no lyme of youre body whille þe mone reyneth in þe signe þat longith to þat lyme
msItem.note: Full transcription; the verse is written beneath a circular diagram showing the cardinal and intercardinal directions in Middle English; the diagram is blank in the centre, but a pinhole indicates that it is an incomplete volvelle, missing its rotating disk.

list.item: Quire 210-2 (ff. 1:1-1:232: 8th leaf after f. 7 and 10th leaf after f. 8 missing and replaced with unfoliated blank paper leaves)

signatures.p: Possible signatures consisting of Roman numerals in brown ink in the right lower-hand corners of f. 4 (v) and f. 5 (vi).

layout.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame and line ruling for single columns of text and tables. 31 lines to the page, written below top line, except for the table headings.

handNote.p: Written by a single scribe in a cursive script with both Anglicana and Secretary features.

decoNote.p: Large circular diagram in brown ink with names of the cardinal and intercardinal directions in brown or red ink.
Large (1- or 2-line) initials in blue, red, or brown ink throughout the calendar.
Headers for columns, and Signs of the Zodiac and numbers in tables highlighted in red ink.
Paraphs in red ink in the text on f. 14r.

origin.origDate: Written in the 2nd half of the 15th century.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Kk.6.33, ff. 2:1r-2:113v

msItem.title: Culinary recipe for Balm Royal
msItem.rubric: 2:1r Thys ys the makyng of Bame ryall
msItem.incipit: 2:1r ffurst take iij quartes of mete oyle of þe best
msItem.explicit: 2:2r þat hit breke not owȝt of þe cloth and þan afterward put hit in a botell of pewter and þat hit be cepte close

msItem.title: Medical recipe to treat gout
msItem.incipit: 2:2v For þe gowte take hennebane mogwort sawge mynt horsmynte watercarsyn cynchoun fenel [? amount] and wyneg wyndraftes and ale draftes and frye ham wel in schepys talw and lay to þe gowte
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Recipe for a plaster
msItem.incipit: 2:2v Recipe lynsed millilote camamille anete rose barly mele of iche half a pound medill alle þese well togedir
msItem.note: The rubric is transcribed as Emplastrum couisis[.] in Connolly (2009).

msItem.title: Recipe for a plaster
msItem.incipit: 2:2v Recipe a neg yrostyd hard and pu away the whyte cle[...]
msItem.explicit: 2:2v and make a plastyr of all thys and ley to the syde þer as the sor hys

msItem.title: Collection of thirty-five medical recipes and charms
msItem.note: The collection contains A charme for brennyng and scaldyng (f. 2:4r), A charme for a breste (f. 2:4v), and A charme for alle manere woundes [= the so-called Tres Boni Fratres charm] (ff. 2:5r-2:5v); the collection ends with the grene oynement (f. 2:10v).

msItem.title: Maxim
msItem.incipit: 2:10v Nobile vingendi [sic: vincendi] genus est paciencia. Vincit qui patitur si vis vincere disce pati
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: On diet and bloodletting, translatio De Phlebotomia
msItem.rubric: 2:11r A wise man and gode leche seyþe that [followed by 'in the monþe of' and the name of the month, repeated throughout the text]
msItem.incipit: 2:11r in þe monþe of Januarij Whit wyn is gode to drynk
msItem.explicit: 2:11v and whoso þis lif lediþ he may be sure to haue his hele and iij dayes þer be of perel þe xv þe xvi and þe xx day
msItem.note: For other copies, see Connolly (2009), p. 302.

msItem.title: Circa Instans (fragment)
msItem.author: Matthaeus Platearius
msItem.incipit: 2:12r Aloen is hote and drye in þe secunde degre
msItem.explicit: 2:12v aspaltum tare of ynde is .h[ote]. and d[rye] in 3. [de]g[re] it is an erþe comyþ out of ynde and it is heuy and stynkyg
msItem.note: For other copies, see Connolly (2009), p. 302.

msItem.title: On perilous days related to the waxing and waning of the moon, two in each month, twenty-four in the year
msItem.incipit: 2:37r Thou shalt vndirstand and wit wel þat in eche monþe of þe yere be ij. euyl dayes
msItem.explicit: 2:39r take mesure and no more for in mene restiþ vertu and that goode holy seyntis whiche helden to hemselfe
msItem.note: For other copies, see Connolly (2009), p. 303.

msItem.title: Plague tract
msItem.author: John of Burgundy (attributed)
msItem.rubric: 2:39r-2:39v I Johan of burgoyn or Johan wiþ þe berd burges of leodye and master of medesyns in þis skrow wiþ goddis helpe þe preseruyng and cure of pestilenc euelis pleynly y puprose to chewe þat ouueþ eny man schal a phision but euery man may be a phisician a preseruer a gouerner and a curater of hymself
msItem.incipit: 2:39v In þe begynnyg þerfor eueri man auoyde gret replecion of met and drink schun baþis and al þing þat sentiþ þe body
msItem.explicit: 2:42v þat þe hert is greuid and suffriþ wherfor minucioun is a non to be had of þe hert veyn and of þe same side

msItem.title: Collection of four medical recipes
msItem.note: For comparable texts, see Connolly (2009), pp. 303-304.

msItem.title: Treatise on Wounds
msItem.incipit: 2:44r The furst for to spek of a wound in general i thynk to begyn at a newe wound made in flech as wiþ knyf or swerd wiþ spere or wiþ arowe or wiþ eny oþer þing
msItem.explicit: 2:47v this oynement is right gode in al synny placis and it is consolodatif and medigatif
msItem.note: With the added title De vulnerum cura.

msItem.title: Recipes for distillations and a list of precious waters
msItem.incipit: 2:70v A gode watir for eche maner siknes: Take cloue de gilofre quibibus maces of eueriche [ounce] 1 comyn [ounce] and of long peper a quarter candi .ij. [ounce] of saffron þe weght of .ij. d[rams] and ane halpeny nad make poudre of al þes þingis
msItem.explicit: 2:75v and who so euer can worche wiþ þes wateris and oylis and askis schuld be namyd more a prophet þan a leche.
msItem.note: For other copies, see Connolly (2009), p. 304.

msItem.title: Instructions for applying a fomentation to a sore
msItem.incipit: 2:86r to this purpose bee made of decocciouns of simple medesyns and thei must be applied to the pacient or the mundificatif be leyd declaraciouns benen iiij. herof
msItem.explicit: 2:86v be not to hard in her workyng lest thei hurt the sore and aftur that to drawe humours to another place

msItem.title: Recipe for a powder to treat a sore or an abcess
msItem.incipit: 2:86r the poudur of antymony medelid wiþ blak sop and anoynt þerwiþ þi tent and put it in þe mowþ of þe festur þe poudur þerof strewid on a kanker or on ded flesch is asouereyn remdy [sic]
msItem.note: Full transcription; added by a later hand.

msItem.title: Recipe for a cleansing plaster
msItem.incipit: 2:86v Recipe wex [ounce] iiij rosyn [ounce] iij turbentyn librum 1 purid hony [ounce] ij mastik thuris mascli sartocol myr aloes safron [? amount] [ounce] ij and in the ende of the sethyng put to thes poudirs aforseid and mak a plaster
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: List of poultices
msItem.incipit: 2:87r Recipe flouris of camamyll anesse sede [? amount] [ounce] ij mele of fenigrek sede lynsede and barly mele [? amount] [ounce] iij oyle of anese and camamyl [? amount] [ounce]
msItem.explicit: 2:87v but as me semyth thei be regenderyng for this is that olde surgyns hade most delyt in

msItem.title: On maturatives
msItem.incipit: 2:87v ffor to draw to tho thingis whiche bethe longyng to digestion of humounis warmyng hem in goode qualite
msItem.explicit: 2:92r in thes thingis aforseyd is that he drawith all maner humiditeis fro the vttirmost place without any noying.
msItem.note: The rubric is transcribed as De maturatuus in Connolly (2009), pp. 305-306.

msItem.title: Medical treatise on mundificatives
msItem.rubric: 2:97v A tretyse of medisyns that bene mundificatiuis
msItem.incipit: 2:97v Of mundificatiuis sum bene febil and esy in her working as hony and all thingis made of hony iuse of apij wormode and mele
msItem.explicit: 2:97v thus is mel roset made in turbentyn clensid and oþer oyles of mundificatiuis here we make an ende.

msItem.title: Collection of seventy-three recipes
msItem.note: With some additions on blank spacs by a later hand.

msItem.title: Medical recipe (?)
msItem.note: Added text in a 15th-century script, including ingredients such as 'Whyt vyn',and 'Tartary'.

signatures.p: Leaf signatures in Roman numerals in brown ink in right lower-hand corners of the rectos of the first halvs of quires.

catchwords.seg: Catchwords in brown ink in lower right-hand corners.

layout.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame only, with occasional line ruling. Single columns. 23-28 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: Written in various cursive scripts with both Anglicana and Secretary features.

decoNote.p: Small (1- or 2-line) plain initials in blue ink.
Headings of texts rubricated in red ink.
Paraphs in blue or red ink.

history.provenance: An owner from or with relations to Daglingworth in Gloucester: inscribed Dallingworthe on f. 113v.

change.persName: Dr Clarck Drieshen, Project Cataloguer in Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries, Cambridge University Library
